name: handoff
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
in American football, a pass in which the ball is put directly into the hands of another player: Flacco faked a handoff and looked to pass. A botched handoff that was meant for him never made it to his hands.
in a relay race, an occasion when a runner puts the baton into the hand of the next runner: The relay team failed to finish the final because of a botched baton handoff from Jones.
in rugby, an occasion when the player carrying the ball puts the ball under one arm and pushes away a player who is trying to tackle him or her with the other hand: He swatted Smith away with a powerful handoff and galloped over the line to complete the scoring. Watch the defender closely to see if the handoff is an option.
US (UK handover) an occasion when one person gives something to another: Drug handoffs are easy to spot. Failure to synchronize actions during hand-offs is visible in medical settings.
[ usually singular ] US informal (also handover) the act of giving control of something or responsibility for something to someone else: the handoff of power to an interim government
